title: Cat. 56.1  Nave nave fenua (Delightful Land), 1893/94
publication_title: Gauguin Paintings, Sculpture, and Graphic Works at the Art Institute of Chicago
content:
<section class="osci-tk-epub-section tombstone" id="tombstone">Nave nave fenua (Delightful Land), from the Noa Noa Suite  
1893/94  
Second state of four  
Wood-block print in black ink, with hand-applied red, blue, green, yellow, red-orange, and silver-gray watercolor on tan wove paper; 354 × 200 mm (image); 357 × 204 mm (sheet)  
Inscribed in the artist’s hand verso, upper right, in pen and brownish-black ink: 10 Mars / PG [0 changed to 5 in the same ink]  
The Art Institute of Chicago, Clarence Buckingham Collection, 1948.261  
Guérin 28, Kornfeld 14 II/IV  
For the verso, see fig. 56.1.1

</section><section class="osci-tk-epub-section technical_report" id="technical_report">One of the most inventive printing campaigns of the late nineteenth century, Gauguin’s Noa Noa Suite distinguishes itself as an enterprise in which the artist worked freely and experimentally with a wide range of papers, disparate media, and unconventional printing and transfer techniques to produce a multitude of impressions. Having purchased ten end-grain boxwood blocks of the highest quality, suitable for both wood engraving with a needle and wood carving with variously shaped gouges and knives, the artist printed all ten blocks as a group at several distinct moments in the block-carving process. He did so in a series of working campaigns, in which he would print the blocks, then revise them, then print them again. Different methods and materials were used in each campaign. These include applications of transparent watercolor washed over printed images; site-specific transfer of opaque, resinous, and waxy media from sheets of glass onto the paper before printing; and multiple, deliberately off-register printings in various inks on single sheets of paper. Close examination of a large number of examples has led to a chronology of production that chronicles the artist’s more rudimentary printing methods as well as unconventional printing techniques in which atypical materials were used at different moments in the aesthetic evolution of the suite.

This hand-colored, second-state impression of Nave nave fenua (Delightful Land) was printed without any manipulation of the matrix such as skewing the registration in a double printing, transferring media from another surface, or selectively wiping the block. Here the block was printed only once in black. The artist brushed colored media over the printing ink to create his desired atmospheric and textural effects.

The multilayer interactive image viewer is designed to facilitate the viewer’s exploration and comparison of the technical images (fig. 56.1.2).

RTI captures the work of art lit from multiple angles to enhance the surface topography of the wood-block print (fig. 56.1.3).

The wood block was printed in carbon black ink (see fig. 56.1.4). After printing, Gauguin brush applied watercolors to tone various passages and set them apart from each other. Barely discernible passages of pink that appear in the distant sky in the upper left and in the foreground behind the figure are a much-faded cochineal lake. Faint passages of dilute ultramarine blue appear in sky as well as in the decorative band at left. Thicker applications of ultramarine blue, as well as a green tone that is a mixture of viridian and cadmium yellow, appear in the flowers in the foreground (fig. 56.1.5). Yellow-orange present in the figure’s body is a mixture of vermilion with cadmium yellow.

The artist also used a silvery-gray wash that he brush applied with great specificity to white-line passages in the composition. Magnification reveals that these brushstrokes contain a great deal of gum that gathers along the edges of the strokes and reflects light, causing the overall silvery appearance. Gauguin’s applications of it appear along the contour of the back of the figure’s proper right leg, in the line that forms the left branch of the forked tree in the right middle ground, and in a series of curved lines below the tree in the background to the right. This medium, here and in other impressions from the Noa Noa Suite, was used to purposefully push bright lines into shadow (see, for example, L’univers est créé [The Universe Is Being Created] [cat. 54.2]).

The paper is a moderately thick, smooth, tan wove paper. The paper fibers in the sheet are distributed evenly, and the paper is of a uniform color. There are no inclusions or colored fibers. The paper is heavily sized. As a result, it remains deeply embossed from the pressure exerted upon it during the printing process. In raking light, the pronounced embossment of the sheet and a series of striations on the verso are products of the artist’s method of printing. The pressure exerted in printing the block on this type of Western paper was substantial. The depth of the embossment signals that the artist likely used his fingertips to press the dampened paper into the interstices of the wood block. In order to fully assess the embossment, surface shape studies were undertaken at the Art Institute using RTI methods adapted for use with photometric stereo to reveal textural characteristics that often defy recognition in normal light. Multiple images captured from a fixed camera position, lit from multiple specific angles, were combined to create an interactive composite image to capture the topography of the surface of the paper (see fig. 56.1.3).

The paper is identical to that used for an impression of Noa Noa (cat. 51.1) and exhibits the same degree of embossment. Under ultraviolet light a pattern of rubbing is visible on the verso of the print, where Gauguin used an implement, perhaps the back of a wooden spoon or handle of a tool, to transfer ink from the wood block to the paper (fig. 56.1.1). From the top to the bottom of the sheet there are a series of vertical strokes that follow the trajectory of Gauguin’s hand. Initially thought to be residual adhesive from the removal of a layer of paper, they do not fluoresce under ultraviolet, nor is there any evidence of residual paper fibers. These instead are byproducts of the artist’s technique.

The edges of the sheet are straight cut although slightly irregular. The paper has been trimmed close to the printed image. There is approximately 1–2 mm of paper margin remaining around the image on all sides.

354 × 200 mm (image); 357 × 204 mm (sheet)

Red, blue, green, yellow, orange, and silver-gray watercolor were hand applied over the printed image. Some of these passages have faded considerably and are better viewed under magnification. From the evidence of color that remains, it is clear that in areas of the print that now appear to be devoid of ink and include those behind the trees and in the brook that runs behind the female figure, dilute washes of red and blue watercolor were used. Although much faded, tide lines visible adjacent to inked passages indicate that the media were applied in a very dilute, fluid consistency in broad swaths (fig. 56.1.6). The nature of the paper prevented the watercolor from penetrating into the sheet too deeply, so it is not possible to ascertain what the unfaded colors would have looked like from examination of the verso. However, examination of the accumulated pigment particles along tide lines confirms that these colors were once much more vibrant. Passages that were once blue are now an almost-indiscernible pale gray. Red passages are now very pale pink. The sky was once awash in pink that blended into blue, hinting that the scene could have been one taking place at sunset or sunrise (fig. 56.1.7) (see also Maruru [Offerings of Gratitude] [cat. 55.2]). Pigments that were characterized using scientific analysis and determined to have significantly altered over time were digitally restored in a recolorized image, which suggests how those passages of the print might have originally looked (fig. 56.1.8). While not meant to be read as an exact representation of the work’s original appearance, the recolorization was based on scientific and visual analysis of this impression and watercolors found in Gauguin’s original Noa Noa, Voyage de Tahiti manuscript, which have been protected from light exposure in the bound volume and are unfaded as a result.

Not all hand-applied media are diminished, however. A brush-applied, deep red-orange vermilion was used on the two winglike forms above the lizard. Here, by taking advantage of the water-based medium’s resistance to the solvent-based printing ink, random patterns of beaded media create a surface pattern that is visually similar to that achieved by the transfer of waxy media found in other impressions. Beading of the red-orange watercolor resulted when it was applied over printing ink that had not yet dried completely. The small, round pools formed as a result of the media’s aversion to the wet oil-based ink (fig. 56.1.9). Similar pools of aqueous color appear in the extended left arm of the female figure, these brushed in a golden-yellow tone. The rest of her body is punctuated by hand applications of this same yellow; however, in these areas it was applied when the printing ink had dried sufficiently to prevent beading of the watercolor.

The hand-colored print was conserved in anticipation of this publication. When discoloration was removed from the sheet, its tone brightened significantly, and the colors now appear more vibrant. Comparison with watercolor passages in pristine impressions from the Noa Noa Suite (see, for example, Auti te pape [Women at the River] [cat. 59.2]), and especially within the pages of Gauguin’s Noa Noa, Voyage de Tahiti, reveals an intensely bright and colorful palette on papers with an ivory hue rather than a golden tone.

The print is in very good condition.  
Harriet K. Stratis and Mary Broadway

</section><section class="osci-tk-epub-section provenance" id="provenance">From the artist to Francisco “Paco” Durrio (1868–1940), Paris, between 1893 and 1895.

Left by Francisco “Paco” Durrio at Kunsthalle Basel for exhibition in 1928.

Walther Geiser (1897–1993), Basel, by Jan. 18, 1931.

Consigned by Walther Geiser to Lucas Lichtenhan (1897–1969), Basel, on Jan. 18, 1931.

Returned by Lucas Lichtenhan to Walther Geiser in 1936.

Sold by Walther Geiser to the Art Institute of Chicago, 1948.

</section><section class="osci-tk-epub-section other_documentation" id="other_documentation">Signed in wood block, lower left, printed in black ink: PGO

Inscribed in wood block, upper center, printed in white-line manner: NAVE NAVE FENUA

Inscribed upper center, upside down in graphite: Guerin no. 28

Inscribed in the artist’s hand verso, upper right, in pen and brownish-black ink: 10 Mars / PG [0 changed to 5 in the same ink]

Inscribed lower left, upside down in graphite: – 5 –

The media and their application, as well as the condition of the artwork, were assessed through visual examination using normal, transmitted, and raking light; microscope magnification (8–10×), and ultraviolet-light examination (254 and 365 nm). The printing ink and watercolor pigments were identified by XRF, Raman microspectroscopy, and SERS. The print was studied by means of photometric stereo.

</section><section epub:type="footnotes" id="footnotes">The locations of eight blocks from the Noa Noa Suite are known. Embossed into the verso of each is the trade name of the manufacturer, Kiessling. The manufacturer’s stamp reads: Kiessling / J Lacroix Suc / PARIS / D 089. Blocks for Maruru (Offerings of Gratitude) (cat. 55.1) and Manao tupapau (She Thinks of the Ghost or The Ghost Thinks of Her) (cat. 60.1) are in the Art Institute’s collection. The block for Noa Noa (cat. 51) is in the Metropolitan Museum of Art, New York, and is described as fruitwood, possibly pearwood. The blocks for Te po (The Night) (cat. 52), Auti te pape (Women at the River) (cat. 59), and Nave nave fenua (Delightful Land) (cat. 56) are in the collection of the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston. The block for L’univers est créé (The Universe Is Being Created) (cat. 54) is in the Memorial Art Gallery, University of Rochester, New York. The block for Mahna no varua ino (The Devil Speaks) (cat. 57) resides in the Bibliothèque Nationale de France, Paris. Gauguin repurposed two blocks from the suite, Te atua (The God) (cat. 53) and Te faruru (Here We Make Love) (cat. 58), by cutting them down and using the backs for a series of smaller prints that he made during his last years in Paris and upon his return to Tahiti in 1895. Two of the segments from the block for Te faruru are in the Národní Galerie, Prague. The segments from the block used for Te atua are presently lost.

I am grateful to Peter Zegers for so generously sharing his insights into the Noa Noa Suite. See Peter Kort Zegers, “In the Kitchen with Paul Gauguin: Devising Recipes for a Symbolist Graphic Aesthetic,” in The Broad Spectrum: Studies in Materials, Techniques, and Conservation of Color on Paper, ed. Harriet K. Stratis and Britt Salvesen (Archetype, 2002), pp. 138–44.

Using the toolbar at the bottom right, any two images of the artwork may be selected for comparison by clicking the layers icon to the right of the slider bar. The slider bar may be moved to transition back and forth between the two chosen images. Where annotations are available, the jagged-line icon brings up a list of them, or colored lines that show the significant features visible in each image, which may be turned on or off in any combination. For example, the red annotation lines, associated with the natural-light image, trace some of the artwork’s key compositional features. When overlaid onto a technical image (X-ray, raking light, ultraviolet, etc.), the red outlines help the viewer to better observe how features in the technical image relate to or diverge from the artwork as seen with the naked eye. (When annotations are turned on, a legend appears in the upper right showing each color and its associated image type.) The circular-arrow icon returns the image to the default settings (natural light, full-image view, natural-light [red] annotation on). The four-arrow icon toggles between the view of the image in the page and a full-screen view of the image. In the upper right corner, the vertical slider bar may be moved to zoom into or out of the image; different parts of the image can be accessed by clicking and dragging within the image itself. The icon in the upper left corner opens a small view of the full image, within which a red box indicates the portion of the overall image being viewed when zooming is enabled.

When the lightbulb icon is yellow, you can change the direction of light illuminating the work of art. To turn off this function, click on the lightbulb icon. To zoom in or out of the work of art, use the zoom function in the upper right of the image viewer (plus/minus signs). To move the work of art in the viewer window, turn off the lightbulb and click and drag the work of art in the direction you would like it to move. To see the work of art full screen, click on the full-screen icon. To return to the original view, click on the return icon (semicircle with arrow).

Pigment analysis carried out by Céline Daher is gratefully acknowledged; Daher, XRF, Raman microspectroscopy, and SERS analytical results summary, Dec. 2015, on file in the Department of Conservation and Science, Art Institute of Chicago.

Time and time again the silvery medium appears in Gauguin’s hand-colored impressions from the Noa Noa Suite (see also Te po [The Night] [cat. 52.1] and L’univers est créé [cat. 54.2]). And in each instance where the same medium is visible on the verso it is an intense black tone. Identification by means of XRF and Raman microspectroscopy proved inconclusive. See Céline Daher, XRF and Raman microspectroscopy analytical results summaries, Dec. 2015, on file in the Department of Conservation and Science, Art Institute of Chicago.

The reflectance transformation imaging (RTI/photometric stereo) research project was undertaken at the Northwestern University/Art Institute of Chicago Center for Scientific Studies in the Arts (NU-ACCESS), generously funded through a grant from the Andrew W. Mellon Foundation. The work of Xiang Huang, who spent countless hours assembling the RTI images that appear in this online catalogue, is especially acknowledged. See Oliver Cossairt, Xiang Huang, Nathan Matsuda, Harriet Stratis, Mary Broadway, Jack Tumblin, Greg Bearman, Eric Doehne, Aggelos Katsaggelos, and Marc Walton, “Surface shape studies of the art of Paul Gauguin,” 2015 Digital Heritage International Conference, ed. Gabriele Guidi, Juan Carlos Torres, Roberto Scopigno, and Holfer Graf, vol. 2 (IEEE, 2015), pp. 13–20, doi: 10.1109/DigitalHeritage.2015.7419447.

I am grateful to Mary Broadway, Andrew W. Mellon Fellow in Paper Conservation at the Art Institute, for creating this recolorization. Our firsthand examination of the artist’s manuscript, Noa Noa, Voyage de Tahiti, provided us with a better visual understanding of the original vibrancy of the artist’s watercolor palette. Works within the manuscript were visually compared to find examples that bore close tonal similarities to the Chicago sheet. Broadway used these to simulate what the original appearance of the Chicago sheet may have looked like.

Visual analysis of Gauguin’s Noa Noa, Voyage de Tahiti manuscript was undertaken in September 2015 at the Cabinet des Dessins, Musée du Louvre, Paris. The manuscript resides in the collection of the Musée d’Orsay, Paris, and access was graciously provided by Leïla Jarbouai, Conservatrice Dessin, Musée d’Orsay, and Musée de l’Orangerie, Paris.

Mary Broadway, conservation report and treatment record, Mar. 2015; Harriet K. Stratis, technical report with black-and-white photographs and color slides of details and photomicrographs, Jan. 1991; Mary Cropley, condition report, Mar. 1988; all in conservation object file, Department of Prints and Drawings, Art Institute of Chicago.

Paul Gauguin (French, 1848–1902), Noa Noa, Voyage de Tahiti, 1893–1901, Musée d’Orsay, Paris, given by Georges-Daniel de Monfreid, 1927, Paris, RF 7259.

Gauguin left Durrio several works on paper from his Parisian studio at 6 rue Vercingétorix prior to his departure for his second trip to Tahiti in 1895. Scholarship is inconclusive as to whether Gauguin gave the works to Durrio as a gift or consigned them to Durrio for sale. González de Durana, Alzuri, and Amezaga, who have researched the relationship between the two artists, reason that the works were likely a gift, because the penniless Durrio was unable to serve as a trustworthy salesman and the works were seen as being of little value since Gauguin left them behind when he returned to Tahiti. See Javier González de Durana, Miriam Alzuri, and María Amezaga, Francisco Durrio (1868–1940): Sobre las huellas de Gauguin, exh. cat. (Museo de Bellas Artes de Bilbao, 2013), pp. 195–98, 219, no. 2. Also see Société du Salon d’Automne, Catalogue des ouvrages de peinture, sculpture, dessin, gravure, architecture et art décoratif, exh. cat. (Compagnie Française des Papiers-Monnaie, 1906), Oct. 6–Nov. 15, 1906, cat. 140.

When Durrio loaned his Gauguin collection to the 1928 Kunsthalle Basel exhibition (see Exhibition History), he received a deposit of 100,000 francs as a guarantee for the return of his collection. Financial troubles forced Durrio to accept the cash deposit from the museum before the conclusion of the exhibition, forfeiting his property as a result. He could not raise the funds in enough time to purchase back his Gauguin collection before it was auctioned off by the Swiss managers of the show. We know nothing of these two people, but one of them could have been the director of the Kunsthalle Basel, Wilhelm Barth; someone with a role in the exhibitons in Basel-Berlin; or someone close to him. Javier González de Durana, Miriam Alzuri, and María Amezaga, Francisco Durrio (1868–1940): Sobre las huellas de Gauguin, exh. cat. (Museo de Bellas Artes de Bilbao, 2013), pp. 195–98.

See Javier González de Durana, Miriam Alzuri, and María Amezaga, Francisco Durrio (1868–1940): Sobre las huellas de Gauguin, exh. cat. (Museo de Bellas Artes de Bilbao, 2013), pp. 195–98. Nave nave fenua (Delightful Land) from the Noa Noa Suite appears in the inventories of Geiser (no. 86-106, Jan. 18, 1931, as Holzschnitte, and no. 68-89, Dec. 24, 1931, as Gravures sur bois, both listed as a set of woodcuts). Photocopy in curatorial object file, Art Institute of Chicago. The collection was purchased in Basel after Durrio failed to return the cash deposit on the works loaned for the 1928 exhibition. Walther Geiser’s collector’s stamp (not in Lugt) is stamped on the verso.

Geiser, who purchased the collection, consigned it to Lucas Lichtenhan for sale on January 18, 1931, as written out in a signed contract; photocopy in curatorial object file, Department of Prints and Drawings, Art Institute of Chicago.

Geiser, as owner of the collection, consigned it to Lucas Lichtenhan for sale on January 18, 1931, but the print did not sell so it was returned to Geiser after they terminateed their contract in 1936; photocopy in curatorial object file, Department of Prints and Drawings, Art Institute of Chicago.

The works in the Paco Durrio, and later Walter Geiser, wood-block prints in the collection of the Art Institute of Chicago have inscriptions on the verso, which were deciphered as the order they were exhibited and presented in the catalogue for the 1906 Salon d’automne at the Grand Palais des Champs-Élysées. This print is inscribed with the number 5, the fifth print in the “Gravures sur bois” section of the exhibition, which corresponds to entry no. 140, “Nave nave Fenna [sic].”

There are two editions of this exhibition catalogue. In the first edition, the exhibition dates are listed as July–August 1928, and the Art Institute’s print is given as cat. 109. See Kunsthalle Basel, Paul Gauguin, 1848–1903, exh. cat. (Kunsthalle Basel, 1928), p. 25, cat. 109. In the second edition, the exhibition dates are listed as July–Sept. 9, 1928, and the Art Institute’s print is given as cat. 219. See Kunsthalle Basel, Paul Gauguin, 1848–1903, exh. cat., 2nd ed. (Kunsthalle Basel, 1928), p. 30, cat. 219.

Collector’s stamp of Walther Geiser, Basel (not in Lugt).

</section><section id="figures">Cat. 56.1 Nave nave fenua (Delightful Land), from the Noa Noa Suite, 1893/94.

fig. 56.1.2 Gauguin’s Nave nave fenua (Delightful Land) (1893/94). The Art Institute of Chicago, 1948.261. Interactive image.

fig. 56.1.4 Gauguin’s Nave nave fenua (Delightful Land) (1893/94) with annotations identifying the pigments and the organic media, the areas selected for analysis, and the scientific methods used in their identification. The Art Institute of Chicago, 1948.261.

fig. 56.1.5 Left, detail of Gauguin’s Nave nave fenua (Delightful Land) (1893/94) with a red rectangle around the area of interest. Right, stereomicrograph showing brush-applied ultramarine at lower left and green watercolor (a mixture of viridian and cadmium yellow) at upper right. The Art Institute of Chicago, 1948.261.

fig. 56.1.3 RTI image of Gauguin’s Nave nave fenua (Delightful Land) (1893/94). The Art Institute of Chicago, 1948.261. Interactive image.

fig. 56.1.6 Left, detail of Gauguin’s Nave nave fenua (Delightful Land) (1893/94) with a red rectangle around area of interest. Right, stereomicrograph showing a dilute wash of red watercolor that is now faded. Faint traces of the brush-applied red watercolor washes, especially along the edge of the brushstroke, are visible under magnification. The Art Institute of Chicago, 1948.261.

fig. 56.1.7 Left, detail of Gauguin’s Nave nave fenua (Delightful Land) (1893/94) with a red rectangle around area of interest. Right, stereomicrograph showing a passage of the sky in the background to which the artist applied washes of red and blue in order to depict a sunrise or sunset. Faint traces of the brush-applied red watercolor washes, especially along the edge of the brushstroke, are visible under magnification. The Art Institute of Chicago, 1948.261.

fig. 56.1.8 Left, Gauguin’s Nave nave fenua (Delightful Land) (1893/94). Right, a digital recolorization of the pigments determined to have significantly altered over time suggests how the print may have originally appeared. The Art Institute of Chicago, 1948.261.

fig. 56.1.9 Left, detail of Gauguin’s Nave nave fenua (Delightful Land) (1893/94) with a red rectangle around area of interest. Right, stereomicrograph showing round pools of red watercolor applied on top of the oil-based printing ink, which acted as a resist. The Art Institute of Chicago, 1948.261.

fig. 56.1.1 Verso of Gauguin’s Nave nave fenua (Delightful Land), from the Noa Noa Suite (1893/94). The Art Institute of Chicago, 1948.261.
